bioghist.p: Otto Landman was born in Germany in 1925. He and his family fled the Nazis when he was 15, emigrating to the United States. He received his master's degree in chemistry and his doctorate in microbiology from Yale University and did postdoctoral work in microbial genetics at the California Institute of Technology and the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Beginning in 1956, he was the civilian chief of microbial genetics at the Army's labs at Fort Detrick. He was a professor of microbial genetics at Georgetown University from 1963 to 1986. In his retirement, he published articles showcasing his research into experimental evidence supporting the long-discredited theory of the inheritance of acquired characteristics. He died in 2003.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Otto Landman. Materials include: course handouts, syllabi, exam questions, annual reports from Georgetown's biology department (1967-1987), and Landman's personnel files from Georgetown; reprints and copies of articles by Landman and others; lecture notes for seminars; handouts and correspondence regarding conferences; lab notebooks and procedure manuals; summaries of research; card files of research and bibliographic notes; and slides and photos.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
